snippet: Life is growing harder in the Syrian capital, President Bashar al-Assad’s stronghold, as residents complain about electricity rationing, shortages of food and gas, and soaring prices.
abstract: Bloody uprising that has coursed through Syria has begun to upend daily life in capital city Damascus, stronghold of President Bashar al-Assad’s government, reordering the lives of residents who complain of hardships as simple as getting to work every day and finding bread; Damascus has not been subjected to demonstrations related to the rebellion, but many residents speculate that perhaps what will drive the city to join the revolt is not demands for more freedoms and political rights but a drastically deteriorated living situation.

byline.contributor: Reporting was contributed by an employee of The New York Times from Damascus, Syria; a Times employee and Hwaida Saad from Beirut; and Liam Stack from Cairo.

lead_paragraph: Life is growing harder in the Syrian capital, President Bashar al-Assad’s stronghold, as residents complain about electricity rationing, shortages of food and gas, and soaring prices.

headline.seo: Damascus Avoids Syrian Uprising’s Blood, but Not Pain
headline.main: Damascus Avoids Blood of Uprising, but Not Pain
headline.print_headline: Damascus Avoids Uprising’s Blood, but Not Pain
